awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: Small: DCM: Collaborative Research: An efficient, versatile, scalable, and portable storage system for scientific data containers
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific Bigdata sets are becoming too large and complex to fit in RAM, forcing scientific applications to perform a lot of slow disk and network I/O.  This growth also makes scientific data more vulnerable to corruptions due to crashes and human errors.  This project will use recent results from algorithms, database, and storage research to improve the performance and reliability of standard scientific data formats.  This will make scientific research cheaper, faster, more reliable, and more reproducible.

The Hierarchical Data Format (HDF5) standard is a container format for scientific data.  It allows scientists to define and store complex data structures inside HDF5 files.  Unfortunately, the current standard forces users to store all data objects and their meta-data properties inside one large physical file; this mix hinders meta-data-specific optimizations.  The current storage also uses data-structures that scale poorly for large data. Lastly, the current model lacks snapshot support, important for recovery from errors.

A new HDF5 release allows users to create more versatile storage plugins to control storage policies on each object and attribute.  This project is developing support for snapshots in HDF5, designing new data structures and algorithms to scale HDF5 data access on modern storage devices to Bigdata. The project is designing several new HDF5 drivers: mapping objects to a Linux file system; storing objects in a database; and accessing data objects on remote Web servers.  These improvements are evaluated using large-scale visualization applications with Bigdata, stemming from real-world scientific computations.

por.por_cntn:
The Hierarchical Data Format (HDF5) standard is a container format for scientific data. It allows scientists to define and store complex data

structures inside HDF5 files. Unfortunately, the current standard forces users to store all data objects and their meta-data properties inside one large physical file; this mix hinders meta-data-specific optimizations. The current storage also uses data-structures that scale poorly for large data. Lastly, the current model lacks snapshot support, important for recovery from errors.

A new HDF5 release allows users to create more versatile storage plugins to control storage policies on each object and attribute. This project is developing support for snapshots in HDF5, designing new data structures & algorithms to scale HDF5 data access on modern storage devices to Bigdata. The project is designing several new HDF5 drivers: mapping objects to a Linux file system; storing objects in a database; and accessing data objects on remote Web servers. These improvements are evaluated using large-scale visualization applications with BigData, stemming from real-world scientific computations.

The major outcomes of the project include:

  1. Virtual File Driver (VFD) for HDF5 has been developed to to support different storage variations. In particularly, we are developing VFD on top of the SSH2 protocol based on libssh2 library(http://www.libssh2.org/). The VFD implementation in HDF5 will enable HDF5 users to manipulate HDF5 files via standard HDF5 APIs remotely via their preferred protocol. The source code of the implementation can be downloaded at our project GitHub repository at https://github.com/lsubigdata/hdf5ssh.

  2. A Database Snapshot System has been designed & implemented in collaboration with researchers from Brandeis University for managing visualization instructions for large time-dependent scientific datasets that are not well supported in current visualization systems. With a simple programming model provided by the snapshot system, one can easily manage versioned visualization metadata & provide new labor-saving visualization system features such as version interpolation.

  3. Improved Vish Visualization Package. The Vish Visualization Shell[5] is a software environment specifically designed to “make everything a plugin”. It manages all its plugins functionally through a small kernel of abstract object interfaces which are used to implement graphics, user interface, I/O, or object relationships itself. This approach allows for modular well-encapsulated components that can be implemented independently of each other.  A versioned metadata module has been implemented in Vish to use Berkeley DataBase snapshots stored in HDF5 format. The module enables us to support useful visualization system features, such as dynamic interpolation of visualization parameters between time points and flexible adjustments of camera parameters per time point. The former allows fast continuous navigation of the parameter space to increase animation frame rate and the latter supports multi-viewpoint renderings when generating Virtual Reality panorama movies.

  4. Visualizations of Gravitational Wave. Werner Benger, the Co-PI of this project has created many visualizations for gravitational wave modeling. In addition to being published in scientific literature, some of the visualizations have been used by LIGO & NSF in articles, web site, & press release. After the announcement of the first confirmed detection of gravitational waves, known as GW1509014 in 2016, the waves were simulated at the Max-Planck Institute for Gravitational Physics according to the observed collision parameters. With the improved version of Vish via the support of this project, Werner visualized the numerical simulation. All these visualizations, including previous ones in other fields done with Vish are rich in color and deep in physics & math. Furthermore, they appeal to both scientific community & general public. The impact of these visualization works are tremendous. More about the visualizations done with Vish can be found at http://vish.fiberbundle.net/
